data.message: When there is a y, e or i after a C or a G, it is a soft sound. So Jif is correct. (Ex: cyber, certain, center, city.  Giant, giraffe, gyro, gentle)

replies.message: With language from dawn of humans it seems there are no absolutes.
Except it's an acronym. And G stands for graphic. Who cares. "PO TAY TO, PO TA TO"
Lol Debby Efnor Buck I was thinking the same thing
Debby Efnor Buck , the first definition of "gyro" is pronounced "jahy-roh".

Tina: SCUBA, laser, NASA, UNICEF, taser, among many others, are pronounced differently than the letters they stand for. Unless you pronounce it "skuh-ba" and "laa-SEER", that is. 

Debby: Never heard of a gyroscope? Gyro doesn't just mean the Greek wrap. Its also short for gyroscope.
There are two kinds of people: those who say "GIF" with a soft g, and those who are new to the internet.
Debby Efnor Buck not when it's a compass
Gift, girth, geyser, giga, girl, gimp...

Statistically speaking words that are the exception to the rule like gift and girl only account for .5% of all English words using the soft G sound. 
That being said, statistically speaking, a statistical argument is rubbish, because statistically speaking there are exceptions to the rule almost 99.9% of the time. Why should GIF be restricted from being an exception to the rule. Almost everyone I know pronounces it with a hard G. And considering that the English language is actually dictated by popular opinion and usage, annnnnnd there is already a registered trademarked word that uses the soft G pronunciation... it not only will end up being pronounced with a hard G, but in a way is legally required.
Or as in gill, gilt, give.
First of all... it's an acronym, not a word. Second of all, the g stands for graphics, which has a hard g like gorilla, not jif.
That rule works en español. English be cray though.
Jonathan: That line of thinking has also been disproved in this comment chain several timesover as well. I suggest once again that you read.

Also the dude who literally created it says its made to sound like jiff the peanut butter. Its not a word. Its an acronym. But also every single letter and punctuation and word is all made up anyway to communicate with one another.
